Comment: The BC Liberals could easily have won another term if they'd listened better to the public.  Their economic record has generally been good, with healthy growth and low unemployment, but they've turned a blind eye to the weakest and most vulnerable amongst us in their unwavering push for budget surpluses.

They've refused to listen to parents who clamor for more investment in schools and teachers, and their record on fighting poverty has been abysmal.  They've left the poor and disadvantaged in a big hole, with welfare rates being very low.  Housing for the poor is a particularly shameful issue; where the government could have intervened early on to build social housing, they instead left it to developers who (understandably) wanted to build high-end condos for big returns instead.

Christy's government in the end came across as hypocritical, cheap, and tone-deaf, and they paid the price.  It will be interesting to see how the party reacts to being out of power!

Comment: This is what is wrong without healthcare in Ontario. OHTAC bureaucrats are not at all concerned with the wellbeing of patients. That robotic surgery is no better controlling cancer or preserving urinary and sexual function is irrelevant since conventional surgery doesn't do a good job at this anyway. The OHTAC panel said the robot’s surgery patients have smaller incisions, lose less blood, suffer less pain and leave the hospital sooner, but that these outcomes don't justify the incremental cost. Longer hospital stays cost more, using precious resources, like doctor’s, nurses and a hospital bed.  With longer hospital stays there is an Increased risk complication like infection. And unless you are a hypochondriac, hospital stays are uncomfortable and demeaning. More pain, is uncomfortable and requires more medication, perhaps even opioids, which can be both expensive for the patient and addictive. But no let’s not have robots.

Comment: If the snake is not in the house, did they look under the hood of their cars ? They go to warm places, hot water pipes, near furnace or hot water heater. 
They are very good at getting into small spaces like a pipe.
One of my sister's pythons got inside a toilet that was not hooked up with no water in it. It would curl up inside the toilet and pop its head out now and then. In it's case, it was looking for a place that wasn't too hot or too cold because the outdoor temperatures were over 110 degrees. 
Once one of her larger snakes went outside in the cooler weather and curled up under the hood of the car, on a warm engine block.
If the snake is found alive they may wish to get a chip tracker put under the skin  or get a snake collar with a tracker on it. 
It is a beautiful snake! Hope it's found alive.

Comment: The Child Benefit program is essentially an admission that our economic system has failed to generate wealth and distribute income in a fashion that can reasonably sustain families. In 1950, North Korea attacked South Korea. The US and other nations came to South Korea's defense. China will protect North Korea. An unprovoked attack by us will lead to a major military conflict.
So, what should those presidents have done?

Comment: Food combining claims to make digestion easier as long as you keep starch and meat separated. Meat & veg, or starch and veg are ok, but no starch and meat together. That's it. My father rigorously "food combined" for about a decade when I was a kid, and a little less stringently so for the past 30+ years. He followed the simple premise of no starch and no meat together, along with only eating fruit until noon each day, that he lost so much weight so quickly that people asked him if he was suffering from something serious! He would respond that he was 'food combining' long before anyone else seemed to have heard of it. Never an overweight man, my dad used food combining, and simply walking to/from his office downtown everyday to keep his weight and fitness in a good way for decades. Based on my father's experience - I would say food combining not only helped with his digestion but had serious weight loss benefits. Like with any other lifestyle change - just check with your GP first.

Comment: I love how the author is using a science basis to support her position. I love how many commenters are agreeing that science should be used to make decisions. AND "Despite extensive investigation looking at the direct effects of chromosome complement4,5,6,7, gonadal hormones and epigenetic influences8,9,10,11,12 on the developing brain, there is a paucity of information that has addressed the multifaceted role of these factors on the progenitor cells that generate the central nervous system—neural stem cells (NSCs)." This is a reminder to all that stating "research shows.." is vague position. Extrapolating results from a model organism to the human condition is likely to mislead.

Comment: "And since our forests absorb much, much more than that"

Except they don't. Forests, in Canada or elsewhere, can be net short-term sinks or sources of atmospheric CO2 depending on the ratio of new growth to fire and decay. Over the past 25 years Canadian forests have been a small net sink of CO2. However this is now and in future at risk of changing due to longer and more intense wildfire seasons and other effects such as warming and drying/thawing permafrost and peat bogs.

http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/forests/report/disturbance/16552

Comment: "Very serious charges should be laid in the case of false accusations".  Let' make this clear...being accused of making a false accusation is very serious and would demand the same standard of proof in a criminal court to prove guilt in a separate court case.  It is not to be concluded that an acquittal of an accused rapist means that the appellant is guilty of making a false accusation.  It does not mean that the complainant is guilty when police decide a case is 'unfounded'.

The incidents of false accusations are seen to be rare and that makes sense when one considers all the reasons the current system fails the victims of sexual assault and further punishes those who get up the courage to stand up for themselves against the assault perpetrated against them.  It is very hard to prove these cases which means it is far more prevalent that victims never see justice.  Because the system fails to bring justice does not mean the assaults never happened and that the complainant lied.

There is an increase of 7% water vapor for ever degree centigrade that the atmosphere warms, and the atmosphere is 1 - 1.2 C . Higher sea level, warmer ocean, warmer air, bigger storms, and flooding that affects millions of people.  Climate change is responsible.   People who deny climate change, especially the O&G industry, are responsible.   Republicans who deny climate change are responsible.

Comment: The article insists most Canadians have access to water that is 'clean, fresh and safe'. Not sure the meaning of fresh, but the clean, safe claims depend on your point of view and your choice of scientific evidence. Health Canada has published the link between THPs (the by-product of chlorine) and cancer - the reduction of which it acknowledges can only be achieved with water treatment devices. While I rely on those for washing and showering, I use bottled spring water or boiled treated water for drinking. The reason for the abundance of caution relates not only to the THPs but to the fact that some microscopic pathogens survive the chlorine treatment. 

My GP doesn't tell clients not to drink the municipal water but he does tell them he encounters issues he suspects relate to residual biological and inert contaminants in tap water. With bottled spring water I am also able to select for a mineral profile that is considered healthy and that is not present in water from my tap.

Comment: I had seven years of university schooling in Canada, and am a university professor -- where I have met many immigrants and foreign students (and I am an immigrant myself). And Chinese students often take on English first names, to make it easier for non-Chinese to know their names. I like both approaches, for it show that foreigners try to integrate into their new land.

I realize your op-ed piece fits into the trendy identity politics favoured by the Globe. Comment: "and the money comes from federal taxes paid by Albertans"

No, Bill, the money comes from federal taxes paid by Canadians.  All of them.  And corporate taxes by Canadian firms.  All of them.  Since the biggest number of each of these is in Ontario, the biggest input to federal resources comes from there, and then each province in turn by population.

...And yes, just to pick an example, the Government of Canada doesn't pay to have any naval bases in Alberta.  So, there's a net outflow to pay for those naval bases.

What's your point:  is it that Albertans shouldn't pay federal taxes like all the rest of us?  I have a lot of respect for Alberta, and Albertans in general, but I don't respect people who misrepresent how fiscal federalism works, or people who grouse about a short-term deficit while having the lowest tax rates in Confederation.  This is called arguing on facts, not "hating Alberta."

Comment: Tesla/Musk does not respond well to people hacking into the cars. One guy did it and posted information about the as yet unreleased P100D he found referenced in the code. Tesla rolled back the software on his car overnight in response. I would bet that any "hacks" applied to a Tesla would be rolled-back immediately. And that is the difference between Tesla and most current cars. You can take a Camaro, Mustang, truck, whatever and apply a "tune" to it and get another 50hp-plus on a normally aspirated car and much, much more on turbo-charged cars. Diesel trucks can get crazy amounts of additional horsepower with just a tune. The manufacturers will not roll that back on you. They might deny a warranty claim, but you still have total control over the vehicle you own. In a recent court case, Tesla was forced to restore full power to cars with Ludicrous mode when owners sued Tesla for lowering the power output that the owners had paid for. They probably did it to lower warranty claims.

Comment: Not a good idea. Automated trains are proven safe reliable transportation. Automated cars are not. The capacity of even automated cars will be far less than that of the rail. It would be a big waste of money. Plus ramps would have to be built to get the cars off and on the guideway. The merging onto it would further reduce capacity. The result would be a huge waste of money and there is a good chance it would not even work. A much better idea is to complete the rail then, when they finally become practical (which could be several decades), use shared automated vehicles (cars, vans, buses) to get people to and from the rail.

Comment: It is unusual to see the benefits given to "status Indians" noted in an article in the Globe: "tax breaks, education funding and other assistance that Ottawa provides to status Indians" in addition to a reference to the fact that funding to aboriginal communities is, at least in part, based on the number of status Indians in the community. 1) If an aboriginal community has signed a land claim settlement (which often involves land and large amounts of money) are its members still entitled to all of these benefits in perpetuity?  I believe they are, but I stand to be corrected.
2) If an aboriginal community has not signed a land claim settlement, are its members are entitled to all of these benefits? Again I believe they are, but again I stand to be corrected.

Comment: Jim, 

Thank you for sharing your personal, heart-wrenching story with us.  You have brilliantly made the point that expecting victims (indeed blaming victims), given the psychology of what happens to the overwhelming majority of them, to go after their predators in criminal court is grotesquely unfair.

Buster strikes me as a very strong individualist whose own sex abuse may not have prevented him from seeking justice in the criminal courts, but his apparent assumption that all victims could have done the same, is utterly unwarranted. Buster is free to reject the notion of "repressed memory syndrome" if he likes, but that does not make him right. Far more important than repressed memory is the suppression of unpleasant memories that we all engage in all the time.

I concur with your repudiation of those who have "little or no empathy" for victims with two caveats--the overwhelming majority here are consumed with empathy for victims, and that empathy extends to Buster, a fellow victim.

Comment: This statement lacks understanding of how electric (and IC engines work). Electric motors usually generate much more torque at 0 speed than an ICE which requires high rpms to produce sufficient power to overcome its own piston compression requirements (remember each piston is only producing power about 25% of the time, and that power stroke needs to power the remaining compression, injection and exhaust strokes) ergo an ICE engine tends to hit its peak torque towards its mid level revs and then needs a gearbox to convert those ~3000rpms into  1 rpm at the wheel. (Diesels tend to have a torque curve that continues to rise with rpms)  Whereas an electric motor generates instant torque at starting thus no need to reduce rpms to wheels, and the rotating magnetic field eventually brakes the amount of current into the stator magnets thus reducing the torque once the rotor is turning. But ultimately the stall torque load of most electric motors is still higher than peak torque in an ICE.

Comment: Agreed - terrorism is a specific kind of violence and should be understood and analyzed as such. Acts of terror have a political goal that stretches beyond the immediate localized consequences of the violence. Terrorists specifically target places and people, and orchestrate their attacks, to generate maximum media attention and cause a maximum public reaction. To say that "every mass shooting is terrorism" is false. Some gangster doing a drive-by on several enemies is not terrorism. Those people don't have political aims and don't care how the general public reacts. A mental case killing their spouse and children is not terrorism. Analyzing motivations and categorizing these attacks *is* a useful and valid exercise especially for law enforcement agencies. It helps them know how to utilize and divert investigative and community outreach resources.

Sure it doesn't have that feel good let's-condemn-everything-equally quality to it, but categorizing these things is valid and necessary.

Comment: Your Grade 4, 1960's  version of Columbus is pretty lame.
Bartholomew De Las Casas transcribed Columbus’s journal and wrote his own History of the Indies.
Of Columbus and his fellow Spaniards, he writes: 
"Endless Testimonies… prove the mild and pacific temperament of the natives… But our work was [to] ravage, kill, mangle and destroy; small wonder, then, if they tried to kill one of us now and then… The admiral, it is true was blind as those who came after him, and he was so anxious to please the King that he committed irreparable crimes against the Indians…"
Columbus "discovered" a land that been inhabited by millions of people for thousands of years. That's not unlike if you go to France and say, "Wow, I just found a new land."
Should Columbus be revered for the above? Doubtful.
Should existing statues be taken down. Difficult to answer. But people are not "looney tunes" for thinking about these questions.

Comment: In actual fact, Halloween used to be deadly serious.  In some European countries, such as Hungary, All Souls Night, October 31st, a vigil was held for the dead as people walked through the graveyards with candles and flowers for the dead (this is still done in Hungary today).  In pre-Christian times this was also a powerful time wherein the barriers between this and the spirit world had grown particularly thin.

This costumed affair in North America (which used to be tremendous fun for me and my friends before government and institutions started to direct how people were to costume themselves) is a deeply degraded version of the original event.  Quite frankly if even it is getting politicized maybe it should just go away altogether.

Comment: A rare but serious complication of measles can occur more than a decade after the infection clears. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is invariably fatal. That does not mean that those suffering that fate have chronic measles. They have no sign of infection and are not contagious. The complications you describe for Lyme are in the same category. A complication that can appear years later, as a consequence of damage from Lyme infection, but the infection itself is no longer there, so chronic Lyme would be a misnomer.

Comment: The vast majority of the debate about these statues ignores historical fact. Many historians that specialize in the Civil War recognize that slavery was the principle cause of the war, and it's reflected in the writings of every single secessionist state's declarations of independence. These statues were mass produced during the Jim Crow era and the Civil Rights eras in attempts to suppress progress.
The very idea of the "state's rights" argument that is so often cited by supporters of these statues is a fallacy that was perpetuated at the end of the war to promote reconciliation between the North and South during Reconstruction.
Further evidence is that General James Longstreet who post-war was pro-reconciliation and black-supporting is not represented with statues. The lack of statues for a pro-reconciliation general shows that the statues were motivated by political goals, not historic preservation.

Comment: Not your best work, John Ibbitson. You're trying to show some sort of equivalence between a Statscan form, and paying huge money to a jihadi who killed someone. The two do not equate.

But let's talk about StatsCan. Have you ever filled out the old long-form census? I have, and I found it highly objectionable. The problem wasn't that it was long. The problem was that it had highly intrusive questions about income, and your money generally. Stuff that you wouldn't even tell your family about. I remember feeling quite angry about having to fill it out. Also note that in the new long-form (which I have also filled out), the Liberals made sure those questions were not included. Regardless of their public pronouncements, the Liberals clearly knew that people objected to the old long form, why they objected to it, and they sanitized the form. So if there actually were users of the old data, they still won't be getting it, because it is still no longer being collected.

Comment: When we consider  the weakest states in the world, the countries that are hybrid democracies and are experimenting with democracy, we see they have immense difficulty dealing with political transitions without resorting to violence, protest and  general strikes. 

That is because interests -bureaucratic, class based and  business - are deeply embedded on both sides of the political ledger. Those out of power stand to lose those gains they achieved while their party ruled. It is an unstable equilibrium.

That is what we are witnessing  in the USA. It explains the constant litany of politically motivated attacks on Trump (including the Globe's). Essentially those elites who once benefited are responding to an agenda they don't like because it threatens them. It is the media's role in all this to mobilize ordinary people to rise up and challenge the legitimacy of the government they oppose.

Don't be fooled by the Globe's claims to objectivity. Their agenda is real and it is partisan.

Comment: Comey did not say that "the Russians did not have any affect on any vote in the last election."
Here's the actual exchange:

BURR: Are you confident that no votes cast in the 2016 presidential election were altered?

COMEY: I'm confident. When I left as director I had seen no indication of that whatsoever.

"affected" and "altered" do not have the same meaning. Burr was asking about hacking of the electoral process itself, not about hacking of news sources, planting of fake news, and the use of bots to rapidly disperse fake news that was gobbled up by some right and alt-right media. Burr was not asking about whether the Russian disinformation campaign affected how people voted; his prepared question, which he read carefully, was about whether votes were altered after they were cast — and that's the question that Comey answered.

Comment: Actually, the electoral college is under no obligation to vote for the candidate of the party on whose platform they got elected. If they had wanted to they could have voted based on the results of the popular vote and elected Hilary Clinton. That's how the electoral college works. They may have cast their votes according to which party they represented, but it was not incumbent for them to do so. It was "designed that way" to ensure at the time that the constitution was written, that the northern states, which had a larger population, did not dominate over the southern states, which they would have if there had there been a direct vote. Since slaves could not vote, by using an electoral college, the south was able to count them as part of their population base (albeit at a rate of 2/3 of a person) and increase their number of electoral college votes. It's an antiquated system that does not reflect the reality of American politics today.

Comment: The "politbureau" remark is off base.  The milk marketing boards, like other supply managed agricultural products,  chiefly represent the interests of the farmers, not the government.  It has been effective at avoiding the roller coaster of disconnected supply and demand.  History proves that the famous invisible hand of the free market doesn't work so well with agricultural products, mostly as the supply and demand elements are a mix of "little guys" and "big guys".   The producers in today's environment face a high level of fixed costs, so that even when prices drop, the supply does not drop.  The current proof is what we are seeing in Wisconsin, with a glut of milk, and prices falling 40%.  

Marketing boards for producers are akin to trade unions for workers.  Should farmers be excluded from what is essentially collective bargaining, which is supported and encouraged by governments,  because they are rural, not urban people?

Comment: The problems of governance and management in health care systems is a long standing dilemma. Back in 1955, Smith identified what he described as the "two lines of authority" - physicians and administrators. While there have been adjustments over time, these two lines still exist.

Research indicates that if greater governance and management authority is assigned medical staff, there are improvements in quality and cost of care (with higher quality actually driving the lower cost). It can also foster innovation and alternative care. Prime examples of this approach is seen with Kaiser (California) and Inter-mountain (Utah). 

However, in our current health system, any such increased and singular authority by physicians can lead to increased costs since the incentives are aligned for them to maximize their income. And there is a large body of evidence that physicians will resist innovations or alternative approaches to care if it reduces their income. Hence the plodding.

Very few dealers have or can easily acquire an EV that they should have in stock - hard to buy when the cars aren't even available to test drive. I wasn't going to buy a Tesla, too expensive. I wanted to save on fuel (spent $600 a month commuting). I needed a minimum range of 130 km, it's math I won't have "range anxiety". I did my research, was interested in the Ford Focus EV, used Fords website to search for on at a dealer to test drive, no Focus EV's within 50km. I emailed a dealer close to me,  got a call 2 weeks later - a customer who had ordered an EV changed their mind (wanted more than 185km range) I drove the all Electric Focus and was incredibly impressed, quick, comfortable and fun to drive. I took the $14k govt rebate which brought the car down to $21k, no gas, little maintenance (brakes, ties). We almost exclusively drive the EV, Love the HOV lane by myself. Great car, there should be 000's on the road. Not an ad!

Comment: There are many pieces of evidence.  Take a look at Area: The forestry industry claims it wants to be sustainable, yet, after 150years of timber extraction in this country, why do forestry companies continue to push further and further into new territory -- often crown land.  Why is it not possible for them to use the forests they already have? Because they can't and remain profitable at the same time. Second, Why are sensitive species that require high quality forest like Woodland Caribou and Spotted Owl now threatened? Third - forestry companies are subsidized because they don't pay very much for the use of the land -- far less than if they owned it. Taxpayers pay for this.  Forth - all this and the decline in the number of jobs and value added products means Canadians don't benefit. If you want a good model of forestry and forest product manufacturing, look to Finland.

Comment: Military services are responsible for establishing age, physical, mental, height/weight, education, drug history and citizenship qualifications for enlistment and commissioning and for continuing on active duty or in the reserves.  The standards are high and strict and would never apply to civilian employment except perhaps for law enforcement.   However, courts have held that Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which ensures all individuals are treated equally before the law with respect to civilian employment, does not apply to the military profession.   Thus, this is not a matter of anyone wanting to join or remain having a right to do so.  Everyone wanting to join must meet all standards or receive a waiver for a disqualifier, of which there are many.  Transgenders should be allowed to join the military if they meet all qualifications, serve in positions and wear uniforms consistent with their biological sex, and do not receive sex reassignment surgery while on active duty.

Comment: AA is not "christian" in any way that would be familiar to a regular churchgoer.  It's founders were members of the so-called "Oxford Group", which held a peculiar set of quasi-christian beliefs in the early 20th century.  AA's theological underpinnings are more problematic - although ostensibly christian, there is no mention of Christ in any AA literature.

The biggest issue with AA is that it insists that alcoholics are essentially powerless and hopeless.  In my view, this is not a good underpinning for recovery from any addiction - in fact, to truly recover, you have to believe that it is possible, and that you are capable of accomplishing it.

AA may work for some (although there are numerous reputable studies that show it's effectiveness to be limited), but only at the cost of subordinating the individual to the AA group-think.  Not a particularly welcome choice in my mind.

Comment: "Should she have  appeared at 18 with her bag packed to return to her native land? Maybe."

I'll give her a truthful answer and say No.  That would have required fairly heroic adherence to our laws.  

But by the same token, she had no right to expect that she would be allowed to break the law in perpetuity.  She had a choice and she made it.  She should be grateful she's not being prosecuted.  She should be grateful she's had this period of her life in the U.S., in freedom  She was not owed that.  

It is unjust to say she is OWED being allowed to stay.  She -- not we --- is the one who chose to put her children at risk of losing their mother.  You do wrong to believe that those who would apply the law don't feel compassion for her and her children.  But if we applied the law only when it feels good, what kind of justice would we that be?  Justice can be hard, and this is a hard case, to be sure.  But because we failed to enforce the law to begin with,  we have this sad, hard case.

All providing jobs using a sustainable resource.  Lumber is carbon sequestration for longer than the forest it came from. Comment: For the most part the coal plants in the USA are not being closed. Rather they are being converted to gas. Basically, gas is cheaper than coal and doesn't produce the air quality problems that coal does. This is bound to continue regardless of the federal government and is not a horrible option for transitioning to net zero power. Most of the new power being built these days is wind or solar as it is the lowest cost option.

Electrical power folk use the term "dispatchable power" to describe power supplies that can be ramped up and down quickly to meet demand. Coal power stations are not dispatchable although coal stations converted to gas operation are somewhat dispatchable. The pick of the litter for dispatchability is hydro. Gas turbine power is also dispatchable.

Comment: Average teaching salary in Ontario is 59 000 (Aug., 2017). It would be interesting to see the outcome if a teacher only worked for four hours. I invite you to walk into a classroom unprepared and spend the day with students. The day that begins at 9:00  "ends" at 3:20 (meaning the students leave). Teachers get 'prep' time that represents a small percentage of the time required to prepare fully (marking/planning/reports/IEPs). One break of 40 minutes (often 25, by the time you hand out pizza, milk, deal with lost shoes, nuts in a lunch, no lunch, student squabbles, etc.). The other break is 20 minutes (as duty is required for the other 20). During this 'break' teachers often coach sports in the gym or provide extra help, or deal with student problems (see above). Teachers put in additional hours before and after the 9 to 3:20 day. Sundays are often a full work  day for many of us. The last two weeks of August involve shopping for school and setting up the classroom.

Comment: In the section "How much college teachers are paid" there was no mention of what part-time teachers up to 6 hours make. Within 'Contract' there is approx. a ratio of 50% partial load and 50% part-time and there is a concern that the % of part-time teachers will increase. At the college I teach at, part-time teachers start at $35 an hour. Most of the part-time teachers that I know make $35-$40 an hour. I am unsure what the maximum a part-time teacher can make. This is only for the hours that they teach. This does not include prepping, marking, faculty meetings, students meetings, answering student emails, helping students outside of the class, parking and mandatory training modules. Some part-time teachers don't have a choice to obtain partial load status where the hours and pay are more and are only aloud to teach a maximum of 6 hours. These part-time teachers who are professionals in their industry are not given the wages they deserve and the support to meet the needs of the students.

Comment: @u5a1a1
Re: "If this were in place for gun show transactions..."

Gun shows are heavily monitored by the BATF and local police and all the vendors selling firearms at a table are licensed dealers (FFLs) who are required to run a background check as a condition of having a license.  Once in a while you will see one or two individuals walking around with a sign saying he has a personal firearm for sale but they do so at the risk of BATF scrutiny and lots of times they sell the firearm to an FFL at the show. So in reality this so-called “loophole” is progressive speak for wanting to pass laws to monitor and control  loans, transfers or physical access of firearms, ammunition, or “high capacity” magazines to distant relatives, friends, domestic partners, roommates or other acquaintances you have known for years. You can see this philosophy reflected in the laws passed in CA, CO, NV, OR and WA

Comment: It's interesting you asked this. There have actually been lots of questions on how to handle intersex people in sports for as long as the Olympics has been around. They used to do sex testing, but they kept (wrongly) identifying women as men due to the plethora of different human sex differences beyond the casually assumed binary. How do we handle intersex people who aren't clearly one or the other? How do we handle transgender people? 

Looking at the evidence is really the best we can do. Transgender women at least are expected to have testosterone levels within cisgender female norms for a enough time to bring their athletic performance within cisgender female norms. That is actually pretty reasonable. But even outside of transgender people, there are all sorts of outliers as far as hormone levels for all sorts of legit reasons. For some strange reason it's only an issue when transgender women are discussed though...

Comment: The overriding issue here is the extent to which social services (including health care) should or can address all instances of high-risk behaviour. Herein, I do not see myself as being mean-spirited, because I did live in the tropics and/or subtropics for nearly a decade. During that time, I kept my vaccinations current and I made myself well-aware of the vectors for microbial and parasitic diseases. Consequently, I remained disease-free, and I made no claims on Canada's public health system in respect of tropical ailments. Is it too much to ask that others should emulate that sort of example? Certainly, failure to do so risks overburdening a system that is already straining to address home-grown ailments.

Comment: Hi, Mary - I had to re-read your comment to understand where you were coming from. If I understand you correctly, you're pointing out that the document to which Michael refers (Gaudium et Spes) suffers from the sexism of its time, and therefore requires correction if the Church is going to credibly proclaim the Gospel to the people of our day, and especially if the Church is going to mount real resistance to the Trump worldview.
I agree, of course, although I don't think Michael was defending the patriarchal worldview of GS and may have actually been assuming that its contents would now be understood in non-patriarchal terms. I don't think that assumption is correct, based on our experience of the last few decades, but to be fair, that wasn't the substance of his essay, either. 
At the same time, I agree that the Church is even more responsible for sexism than Mr. Trump's inane comments are, and that we can't assume we have what it takes to correct others until we correct ourselves. -M

Comment: "Medicare is partially administered by outside agencies

First, other government agencies help administer the Medicare program. The Internal Revenue Service collects the taxes that fund the program; the Social Security Administration helps collect some of the premiums paid by beneficiaries (which are deducted from Social Security checks); the Department of Health and Human Services helps to manage accounting, auditing, and fraud issues and pays for marketing costs, building costs, and more. Private insurers obviously don't have this kind of outside or off-budget help. Medicare's administration is also tax-exempt, whereas insurers must pay state excise taxes on the premiums they charge; the tax is counted as an administrative cost". 
https://www.forbes.com/sites/theapothecary/2011/06/30/the-myth-of-medicares-low-administrative-costs/#4521302c140d

Comment: Globalization can be a big factor in this, so I don't disagree when people call attention to temporary foreign worker programs, etc. And in some cases we see some people over-educating in sectors that aren't related to employment. I think we should also be honest about how the expectations for older workers have shifted over the decades (e.g. removal of mandatory retirement). The massive problem I see is the unwillingness of many companies to invest in training or loyalty to their staff. I'm not suggesting it should be feasible to punch a clock for 40 years at the same place, but social and employment considerations should be a big part of the math as we formulate special tax treatments and support for companies.

My biggest hope in this conversation is that older folks who also faced real struggles in their youth take the time to actually see how the world today might be tougher - and for a longer period of time - than in the past. Lectures on entitlement help nothing.

Faraday has some serious questions to answer about its business operations, but the technology seems to be the least of their concerns.

Comment: Re 'Transferring Stock' it should be noted that if one transfers a stock into a registered account at a capital loss than one cannot claim the capital loss as the CRA deems the loss to be 'Nil' for such a transaction.

In order to be able to claim the capital loss, sell the stock from the non-registered account and put the proceeds into the TFSA/RRSP - but then if you still want to hold the same stock in the registered plan, do not purchase it for at least 30 days or else the original capital loss will be deemed 'superficial' and again, disallowed.

Comment: I wouldn't be so quick to assume it's the fault of the French immersion. My kid is in the regular English program, grade 2.  I send him to extra math class because I find what he learns at school is scattershot.  The homework I see does not have practice questions in gradually increasing order of difficulty.  It jumps around, and doesn't reinforce what he's learned.  As a mathematician, I'm regularly aghast at the material he brings home.

In contrast, at the extra-curricular math, each week they have: 
- Drills in addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.  The point of the drills is fluency.
- And "word problems".  They learn 1 new type of word problem about every 3 weeks, and practice about 6 questions a week.  They also periodically review what they've learned this year.  

I've seen a huge change in attitude since he started taking these classes.  In September, he would say "I hate math, it's hard".  Now he says "Of course I'm good at math, it's easy".

Comment: John Kawamaoto, 

Thanks for the info on the Contingency Fund (CF).  You assert that 1) no corrective action was taken by management to control cost, and 2) it would be irresponsible to continue to fund rail.

1) HART construction contracts are fixed price contracts with fixed duration from the time notice to proceed is issued.  When a contract is signed, the cost is set.  The contract price is changed only when HART issues a change order (which is what a CF is for).  Unexpected events, e.g., a work stoppage beyond HART's control (from strikes, lawsuits and disasters, natural or otherwise) are not in the budget except as a CF item.

2) If funding for HART is cut off, It will mean $billions of Fed funds must be returned and $multi-Million to be spent to terminate existing contracts.  HART will receive no Fed funds after that.  Do you believe that's the better alternative?    

This will  be my last comment on this issue.  Sayonara.

FM

We don't talk about drunk violence when an inebriate intentionally injures or kills someone. We don't talk about vehicular violence when a driver intentionally injures or kills someone. In Byzantine practice, for cheirotonia (major orders--deacons, priests and bishops), the laying on of hands while invoking the Holy Spirit is uniquely performed behind the iconostasis, where as with cheirothesia (minor orders) the laying on of hands is performed in front of the iconostasis. That is proof positive that despite the fact women and male deacons had different functions, and were always listed after male deacons in honour lists, they were equally recipients of the sacrament of Holy Orders. 

Evidence of women deacons in the West is, according to Gary Macy, evidenced as late as the 12th century, but, to the best of my knowledge the essential proof of the status of their ordination as a Major Order is Byzantine alone.

Comment: I recently flew to Europe from Vancouver with Air Canada.  As I am 6'2", I am willing to spend extra to have a little more room on these flights

I brought this to the attention of Air Canada and asked them to provide a seat with more leg room and they went on a mantra about how the incremental fee was for either more leg room or being closer to the front of the jet.  I told them I could care less if it was mid, front or back, I only wanted leg room and I had made my payment for these seats.  I was given the run around.

I am not sure if Air Canada will refund the incremental fee (wait and see if they process a credit). I recognize this is a lesser issue than being kicked off of flights altogether, but just another example of the BS airlines get away with.

Comment: No, this largely errant. Most regeneration of forest, particularly in the richer ecosystems, is a mixture of planted and natural ingress. In fact, in almost every case, a logged area needs a 'regeneration survey' to determine the amount of planted stock need to augment existing advanced regeneration on the ground. In some cases, most of the stocking will be artificially reforested, in many cases it's a mix. 

The biomass removed in the form of lumber represents the extraction, largely, of cellulose, carbon if you will.  carbon comes from the atmosphere. The nitrogen so vital to maintenance of the soil capacity is found largely in the slash material, needles, leaves, small branches etc. This is what is left behind although it is unsightly it is ecologically vital.

In fact, there is a well documented ecological process called the Assart effect, accelerated nutrient mineralization from decomposition of slash materials leading to a richer soil substrate.

One thing was made crystal clear in a Wednesday press briefing on the Senate Intelligence Committee’s probe into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election: this investigation is a very big and very serious deal.

In an hour-long appearance, committee Chair Richard Burr (R-NC) and Vice-Chair Mark Warner (D-VA) framed their probe as one of most ambitious investigative efforts ever taken on by a congressional committee. Comment: I think this article chooses to ignore the more common sense complaints made by those of us who don't like the way this city is currently being developed.  We can accept that some houses will be torn down and replaced with apartments in the name of density, but too often these numbers are used to justify wasteful and short-sighted building practices.  For instance, in the case of the Eastmoreland sequoia lots (a story I imagine developers and sympathizers of this article scoffed at), the neighborhood offered a very viable plan to build two smaller houses on the property without clearcutting the land, along with compensation for preserving the trees.  Such houses would have been more affordable, and saved a valuable public resource: big trees.  This option was rejected because the developer didn't have kit houses of the right size and shape available.  A little creativity, common sense, and smarts could solve both the issue of density and destruction of the things we like about PDX.

Comment: My favorite source on Francis has always been G.K. Chesterton's "St. Francis of Assisi."  I always have assumed that Francis' given name - the one he gave back to his father standing there naked in his birthday suite - is/was Giovanni di Bernardone.  

Chesterton does a great job of telling the story of the psychological and spiritual transformation from Giovanni ["le troubadour" or lead singer of the medieval traveling troupes] to Francesco (actually means "little Frenchy," a nickname really), the self-described "le Jongleur de Dieu" or the clown or jester of God.  Francesco's becoming "le jongleur" allowed him to embrace the freedom he gained from evangelical poverty so he could now sing of "Brother Sun, Sister Moon."

[I came across these themes when studying the "History of Theater and Drama" - specifically medieval theater.  Francesco as a singing poet was certainly familiar and consistent with this artistic genre.]

Comment: Gathering signatures for placing a referendum on the ballot is always done by those in favor of it. They will give a verbal explanation of it reflecting that, so the title matters little at that point. Richardson's rule reflects this reality and allows more people an opportunity to consider placing a referendum on the ballot, but does not vote it into law.

Once on the ballot, the title becomes very important since, as the editorial notes, many only read the title. The party in power has the most say on the title and often will title it in a partisan fashion, requiring litigation in the courts to get a balanced title. Meanwhile, signatures cannot be gathered, which could keep the referendum off the ballot entirely. This encourages the party in power to title unfairly any referendum they oppose. Richardson's proposed rule mitigates this tactic somewhat, allowing the referendum process to work as intended. He is not placing a thumb on the scale so much as taking one off. Others remain.

Comment: "The actions of the Harper government in taking everything about Khadr to the bitter end, no matter how weak their case was, was the opposite of good practice."

Alceste: Actually, the exception to  your "good practice" assertion is Charter litigation. Charter violations must be litigated in order to establish the breadth and extent the of protections the constitution affords Canadians. I recall reading a paper a few years ago, which I believe was written by a law professor in the Charter's early days, in which it was argued that the Charter would have little concrete meaning to Canadians without a body of litigated judgments and precedents. Most importantly, the Khadr case would if litigated have delineated the extent to which Charter rights can be infringed for the sake of enforcing national security objectives as well as the extent to which one's own behavior can mitigate Charter damages (i.e. moral hazard). The value of such clarity is priceless.

Comment: Depends on what you mean by "make a pass."

If it involves sexual touching, the other person has to consent first, otherwise it certainly is sexual assault.  

Maybe I understand what you're getting at.  In social situations (not the workplace) people will often negotiate consent nonverbally.  We move in for a kiss very slowly and incrementally.  Then the other person will either signal that they want to kiss you too, or keep their distance if they don't.  That's not a problem.  That's just asking for consent without using words.

But if you are getting mixed signals -- if you are unsure -- you can either drop it, wait to see what happens, or use your words.  That's how we avoid making "mistakes."  It's just plain wrong to force yourself on somebody.  I suspect you know that.

Comment: From reporting on Harvey, I'd say Harvey response by far topped Katrina's response.

I was a 1st responder to Katrina in NOLA.  FEMA barred search and rescue efforts for days after the hurricane left.  Federal, state & local law enforcement agencies of the SE states were ready to respond before the hurricane hit & started towards or were already in NOLA the day after it hit. LEOs from around the country were also on their way.  FEMA immediately put out a stand down order to all federal law enforcement until FEMA decided it was safe to enter NOLA.  FEMA also claimed that those LEOs from the gulf states don't know the immediate needs of persons/cities that were hit by hurricanes.  DUH!  Our purpose Was search, rescue & to make the city safe.  NOPD had very few officers left to aid in this effort due to being stranded, killed, or just fled the city in the midst of the damage and chaos. & who knows more about the needs of hurricane victims than those who survived numerous of them.

psychology: is it important to know ourselves and how others respond to who we are ...?

physiology: is it important to understand how we grow and what makes us look different at the same age ...?  Certainly!

Comment: Comfort and your respect for it aside, using epidurals and medications during labor and birth introduces risks also. Setting up any option as one with "absolutely zero risk" is fallacy. This is the excellent thing about choice in our community, we get to evaluate and choose our risks relative to our personal values. (This is where one would ensure "informed choice".)

There are also plenty of mammals who do birth in water, and this article didn't spend much time on people laboring in water and then "hauling out" to actually deliver. That happens quite a bit--I'd be interested in seeing stats but anecdotally, I think it's 50/50 that labor happens with water support but birth happens out of water.

The lead of the article sums it up, factual research about the safety of water birth is drawing praise and worry for the option. With better information comes better training and technology so expecting parents and their care providers can work together toward safer outcomes.

Comment: Algae in storage reservoirs is never eradicated. Rather it CAN be controlled by use of copper sulfate. In a reservoir like the one Wellington gets raw water from, using copper sulfate is frowned on because copper ion levels in trout bearing waters can destroy the "alevins" or newly hatched baby trout. Thus, even though there may be no breeding populations of trout, the EPA in all its glorious splendor prohibits using copper sulfate. The chemical in low concentrations is nontoxic to humans and livestock. Your daily vitamin supplement probably contains copper sulfate.

Comment: Because of friends in religious congregations and because I checked out the distribution reports of the Retirement Office a year or two ago, allow me to make this generalization: The preparedness for  retirement expenses varies wildly between congregations and between provinces within the same congregation. In general, those congregations whose alumni or alumnae became wealthy are in better shape than those who taught in contract schools, that is, parish schools or diocesan high schools. Few convents are still available to the Sisters who taught in the parishes. Just as with lay folk, each province has had to make plans for the future. Some overbuilt houses of independent or assisted living, and each death or move to a nursing home emptied the retirement home. One province simply hired a capable nurse to locate the appropriate nursing home anywhere in the state, and have the religious live there alone except for check-up visits, under Medicaid. We do support our friends' congregations.

Comment: Another view from 35,000 feet is that this presale flipping activity is just another symptom of too  little supply of homes - condos in this case.  This only works in a rapidly rising market and the speculators are taking a risk of losing their deposits if the market suddenly drops, as it did in 2008 .  In that case buyers were suing the developer to get out of their contracts rather that pay the contracted price for the finished units ( Olympic Village). As I recall the developer went broke and the City of Vancouver lost the money that it was owed for the land that it had sold.  Developers beware - this could happen again and you won't have any satisfaction chasing foreign investors for the completion price in China's courts, nevermind ours. Locals who invest will be on the hook however. It's another reason to prohibit foreign purchases of Canadian real estate. The damage done by market destabilization outweighs any benefit provided by foreign capital.

Comment: At a Port of Entry they are not in Canada so the Safe Third Country Agreement designating the USA applies.

Once in legally or illegally then under the IRPA implementing our international refugee protection obligations, the claim to refugee status must be assessed and the Charter of Rights and Freedoms applies.  This was confirmed by the Supreme Court of Canada over three decades ago.- Singh v. Minister of Employment and Immigration, [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177.

Per Dickson C.J. and Lamer and Wilson JJ.: Appellants, in the determination of their claims, are entitled to assert the protection of s. 7  of the Charter  which guarantees "everyone ... the right to life, liberty and security of the person and the right not to be deprived thereof except in accordance with the principles of fundamental justice". The term "everyone" in s. 7  includes every person physically present in Canada and by virtue of such presence amenable to Canadian law.

Comment: This market won't hold. Vegas is the new Denver and prices are less expensive. By 2019 there will be even more alternatives to offset the supply vs. demand. Look at BSL.gov (population & unemployment), indeed.com (job openings), the actual population of millennials who need to pool their money together to afford current home prices, and Denver trends in home buying over the past 25 years. The reality is we have mountains which are very cool, but we also have the potential for harsh winters and no ocean like San Francisco. Comment: a man who had fallen among thieves
lay by the roadside on his back
dressed in fifteenthrate ideas
wearing a round jeer for a hat

fate per a somewhat more than less
emancipated evening
had in return for consciousness
endowed him with a changeless grin

whereon a dozen staunch and leal
citizens did graze at pause
then fired by hypercivic zeal
sought newer pastures or because

swaddled with a frozen brook
of pinkest vomit out of eyes
which noticed nobody he looked
as if he did not care to rise

one hand did nothing on the vest
its wideflung friend clenched weakly dirt
while the mute trouserfly
confessed a button solemnly inert.

Brushing from whom the stiffened puke
i put him all into my arms
and staggered banged with terror through
a million billion trillion stars.
 e e cummings

I'm inclined to believe your statement about under reporting of sales, but that's a civil law enforcement matter.  Under reporting of cash income is by no means limited to cannabis stores.  States have had the same problem with under reporting of liquor stores sales since the day Prohibition was repealed.  

But it certainly highlights the mistake that states make when they see Big Tax Buck$$$ as the result of legalizing cannabis.  If states weren't so greedy, if they didn't impose usurious taxes on these products, there'd be a lot less incentive for stores to under report their sales.

Comment: Yep, there will be a little more delay in the previously withdrawn Loafer Timber Sale while the Umpqua National Forest prepares more supportive paperwork.

The Western Environmental Law Center declared this sale delay a "victory" on their web site. Seems a little early to call "victory". What will the end result be? A token reduction of sale acreage or road reconstruction?

The lamented Umpqua Hot Springs has become an overused and often lawless ecological disaster. Remove the bridge over the river and close the access road to return it to the less used more pristine condition it enjoyed when I first hiked in 45 years ago. That would be a small but real "victory"!

How much have enviro lawyers made from Loafer litigation so far? How much more will additional Forest Service paperwork cost taxpayers? 

What's up ahead? Will a timber industry friendly congress use this litigation and the many other timber sale law suits to justify privatizing public land or diminishing protective laws?

Comment: EU open borders were an amazing advantage up until they were abused by the mass migration of illegals from Africa and the Middle East a few years ago. The free movement of actual European people within the EU has been a boon to the overall EU economy. Britain has enjoyed two decades of economic growth as a result. 

The challenge now is to remove the illegals from the EU, to properly tighten up the frontier borders, and to restore free movement for European peoples only (Eastern Europe is the leader on this). Any European country that does not do that (Germany, Sweden, France, Greece) need to have their citizens restricted from free movement until such time as their governments honour the original principles of the EU. Open borders was never about a free-for-all for the people of the third world.

Comment: Part 1:

I don't think Jesus spoke in a didactic way about the relationship between justice and mercy; Jesus' teaching unfolds in his parables and in the Sermon on the Mount, especially the Beatitudes.  Of course, the church has been reflecting on his teaching, trying to understand and follow it, for more than two thousand years.  We live in the "time between the times" -- the "already" of the reign of God inaugurated by Jesus and the "not yet" of the full realization of God's reign in God's time.  In the time between the times, we seek justice and practice it imperfectly.   In the reign of God, God blends justice and mercy perfectly, because God is Love; but we do it imperfectly.  At least, though, we must keep both in view and recognize the priority of mercy without denying the importance of justice.  What an awesome task, especially for those in the church, charged with ministering to sinners, and those (like you) in civil society, charged with administering justice. (con't.)

Comment: There is a difference between those with high incomes, and those with wealth.

You can build wealth with a low income. And in fact, my in-laws are make poverty level wages, have more wealth than this doctor.

My aunt, who has worked at low wage jobs all her life as a cleaner, and her husband, also a low wage jobs, have managed to be millionaires in their late 50s by buying Vancouver property. 

As a lowly family doctor in my mid-30s, with a child and a stay at home wife, my net worth is 2.5 million, 1.3 million in investable assets that generates 45K a year of dividends. Not all of us doctors are financially inept.

And we don't live poorly. I take the train to work (takes me 20 minutes), we have one luxury SUV that is 6 years old. We eat out when we want. We just don't buy new vehicles or lease vehicles every few years. It's all about prioritizing, saving, and investing.

Comment: Quebec's reputation as king maker stemmed from the tradition of a "Quebec solide"-where Quebec would overwhelmingly move to either the Conservatives or the Liberals. In the two-party era, that was often decisive. With more parties in the mix in Quebec (and elsewhere), coupled with its declining share of the total seats, Quebec's impact is attenuated, and greatly influenced by seat distributions elsewhere. At the same time, the perception that a party and its leader are competitive in Quebec , may well influence the propensity of voters in other provinces to take them seriously as an alternative government. I think O'Leary's rationale was entirely credible.

Comment: "If the American President does not respect the American Constitution, then the USA has effectively ceased to exist."

Were that true, the USA would have become an historical footnote long ago. Some presidents have been seemingly unaware of the Constitution, let alone respectful of it. But the strength and genius of the Constitution isn't in the office of president alone but in the separation of powers.

At various times, the executive, legislative, and judicial branches have each been run by persons who were weak, self-serving and even criminal. But never all three at the same time to the degree that the nation was in danger of collapsing, thank God.

I'm not saying it can't happen, but it will take more than just an incompetent president. For Trump to destroy the USA he'll need some help from the other two branches of government.

Comment: It's not about taking away the PFDs, it's the principle. People in OK and TX don't collectively as a state own any rights to the oil. If you are/were a lucky soul to own land and big oil pays you to drill on/in it, you got rich. We can't do that here. The people of Alaska are stakeholders since no private person can own land and let big oil tap that oil out. The question people are now asking is, why are they capping or possibly removing something that was given to us as a (state) constitutional right, when there are huge tax credits to big oil that haven't been renegotiated to relieve burdens on our existing state budget? Wiki explains why PFDs are a right this way: "Many citizens also believed the legislature too quickly and too inefficiently spent the $900M bonus the state got in 1969 after leasing out the oil fields. This belief spurred a desire to put some oil revenues out of direct political control." Thanks Wiki!

Comment: Richard, if you are buying a purple car, do whatever you like. If you are using someone else's money to do it, you need to follow whatever conditions are attached to the use of that money. The public official and landlord clearly acted to circumvent the rules attached to the use of public funds. 

If the public official were using his own money to fund such a idiotic arrangement, I doubt anyone would have a problem with it. But, as it turns out, he used public funds. Therein lies the problem.

I worked on a construction project many years ago and a purchase was made with company funds without the appropriate approvals. When it was discovered that this happened, the buyer was unceremoniously terminated. Had it not been a legitimate purchase, the company likely would have pursued criminal charges.

So, why should a public official be held to a lower standard than a buyer in the private sector using company funds?

Comment: The problem with Krugman's thinking, if it is indeed possible to limit that to only one problem, is that all his solutions revolve around spending more taxpayer dollars with the hope that preventive use of medicine will reduce the overall cost, then assuming everyone's costs will eventually go down. Sadly, there is no evidence of that dynamic ever working in the long run. In fact, as an economist, Krugman should know that it is contrary to basic economic principles. When people are getting something for below market price or for free because others are paying the difference, they will tend to use more of it. As that happens, and since there are always limits to tax dollars and the political costs of deficit spending, rationing happens by various means. For Medicaid, it is doctors dropping out of that market, leaving those reliant on it with longer waits and lower quality doctors and care, even as our overall expenditures on Medicare go up. Even a Nobel prize winner can be wrong.

Comment: Discussion of gravity waves has been ongoing for many decades.  Gravity waves are similar in concept to electromagnetic waves, i.e. radio, light, X-rays, etc.  Gravity, however, is much weaker than electromagnetic forces.  Just as electric current moving back and forth in an antenna creates radio waves, objects moving around each other in orbits emit gravitational waves.  Because gravity is so much weaker than electromagnetic forces, it takes truly massive objects to make gravitational waves we can detect.  Everybody expected gravitational waves to exist, the challenge was to make a receiver sensitive enough to detect them.  Basically no practical importance as far as human existence is concerned.  However, the detection of the gravitational waves is a brilliant feat of experimental physics.

Because Plato wrote, he has many more students than Socrates. Yet Plato wisely recognized a decisive advantage in the Socratic method: Socrates could attend to the particular and individual characters of his interlocutors. Philosophy is not simply an intellectual or technical achievement, for which writing would suffice. It demands virtue, sustained moral attention, and the complete participation of the soul. Since they are aimed at a mass market, the legal systems are mostly modeled after either California or New York.  The law is very State-specific, particularly on the criminal side.  Grand Jurys are done differently in Oregon, California and New York, for example.  

There is also the total difference between small legal offices and larger offices.  Even in Oregon the We The People Firms in Portland have little to do with legal practice in much smaller offices and communities.

Then there is always the simplification of the law, the facts, and the investigations, whether in a criminal or a civil case that has to be built in to a television movie or series.  

Law is basically boring repetitive Work!  Research is mandatory.  Without  Detailed preparation, you will lose!  When you ask a question or hear one being asked in a courtroom of any witness, if you don't already know the answer, you are not prepared.  

That doesn't happen without work.

Comment: For the most part this story is factually correct and on-point about some important need areas. There is however one factual error that I think resulted from the writer's lack of understanding of Education terminology as it is used in Hawaii.

The sentence "...Hill detailed the stories of two educational assistants..." implies an idea that is incorrect. The two individuals in the recent stories were not employees of the HIDOE. They were employees of two companies that are contracted by the Department to provide specific services to children whose IEPs specify having "Skills Trainers."

Educational Assistants are paraprofessionals who are employees of the Department and must meet certain educational and experience requirements before they are hired to work in the schools. The interview process for EAs is very similar to that for teachers. (Many EAs continue their education and become certified teachers.)

Comment: Regarding: "Are parish assets immune from liquidation?"
- Perhaps the reason why this question is asked is that early on in the discovery by the laity of the rape of children and molestation of young people by clergy, the episcopate in the US said often that the transfer of diocesan wealth to the victims would not come from the 'collection basket'. Thus implying somehow that the assets of the diocese were separate from work and beneficence of the laity.
- Canon law requires that each parish be its own separate civil entity. However in almost all US dioceses the parishes are part and parcel of the 'bishop, corporate', or some other civil entity that can be manipulated in similar manner.
- So, the short answer is, parish assets are not immune from liquidation. Further, it is conceivable that the bankruptcy court can take a percentage of each collection in the parish to meet the diocese's legal obligation. Legislatures certainly can lay a legal foundation to further enable this.

Comment: This goes back to Harper's 2008 firing of Linda Keen, who was the head of the CNSC and had warned about safety at and was fired for shutting down Chalk River in 2007.    This reactor was an important supplier of global medical isotopes so the shutdown affected supplies.

Keen was fired because Harper and Gary Lunn (who fancied themselves as "experts") disagreed that there were any safety concerns at Chalk River.     The reactor was brought back online in December 2007.

In December 2008, there was a heavy water leak in the NRU reactor at Chalk River.   This leak worsened and in 2009 the NRU had to be shut down completely.    Repairs took until 2010.   So it turns out Linda Keen was correct.    Of course, the Harper govt had neglected to plan for medical isotope supply backups, and the second shutdown caused a global medical isotope shortage  (a crisis which Lisa Raitt labelled as "sexy").

Time to fix another Harper mess.

"On August 25 Ted Kennedy—a longtime healthcare reform advocate—died. Paul Kirk was appointed as Senator Kennedy's temporary replacement on September 24. The bill then passed, also 60–39, on December 24, 2009, with all Democrats and two independents voting for it, and all Republicans against (except Jim Bunning, who did not vote)."

"On January 19, 2010, Massachusetts Republican Scott Brown was elected to the Senate in a special election to replace Kennedy, having campaigned on giving the Republican minority the 41st vote needed to sustain Republican filibusters. Comment: Traditionally, Jews and Muslims are buried in a plain shroud, but the law required a coffin, so there was a plain pine coffin. The male relatives carried it to the grave. The rabbi recited the (four-line) El Male Rachamim, the mourners recited the (fifteen line) Mourner's Kaddish, the coffin was lowered into the grave and everybody took turns forking some dirt onto it. Then the miniature bulldozer finished the job. There was some ceremonial rending of garments, but obviously not real garments, just ribbons provided for the purpose.

No promises, no fantasies, no feudal pageantry, no exploiting the occasion to frighten anybody into being obedient. Nothing left to be said. If there is a God, the rest is up to Him. If there is not a God, the Jews will continue to worship Him, because that's what being a Jew is about.

I was impressed. Much more dignified, I thought. Kind of sorry I have to have the other thing, but of course, at that point I won't really care anymore.

Comment: The Electoral College reflects the Senate's composition, with its emphasis on land mass rather than population.  This can be changed.

The Senate, created in the Great Compromise that kept southern slaveholders in the Union, was elected by the state legislatures.  The elimination of the direct role of the people in electing the Senate was not rectified until the 17th amendment was ratified in 1913. 

Perhaps the article's writers would happily defend the corruption of pre-1913 choice of Senators as much as they do the use of 3/5 of the slave population to amplify slaveholder representation in the House and thus the Electoral College.

They misleadingly omit Lincoln's overwhelming plurality of the popular vote -- more than twice his leading competitor.

It's worth noting that now that the African-American vote is suppressed "with almost surgical precision," as a Federal Appeals Court wrote this year.  But they now contribute a full 5/5 of the census, rather than 3/5 as in slavery times.

Comment: I don't know.  Your statement is again, pretty general and I'm not certain the wording is true, because I'm not entirely certain what you mean. It's part of understanding the First Amendment.

My point is we communicate untrue statements about these things all the time, and it perpetuates misconceptions.  I attended a seminar once on managing conflict among staff.  The presenter, a science PhD, proudly stood in front of the room and declared to 200 people that "The First Amendment does not protect you in the workplace."    

Is that a true statement?   No.   The First Amendment does not protect people from being fired, which is what she meant.    But it does, or is supposed to, protect you in the workplace.  She had difficulty understanding why her statement was incorrect.

[Bolton violated the law by denying him a jury trial.]
What is the law in question?  That an accused person is entitled to a jury trial.  This is without limitation?  The Supreme Court determined various limitations when it comes to jury trial.  For example, jury trials with six people empaneled must be unanimous but not twelve.  But to the actual case:
No jury trial is required, however, when the maximum sentence is six months in jail, a fine not to exceed $1,000, a 90-day driver's license suspension, and attendance at an alcohol abuse education course.  Blanton v. City of North Las Vegas, 489 U.S. 538 (1989)
How long was the maximum sentence Arpaio faced?  Six months.

Comment: The BOG for years has pursued policies and associated regulations that favor harvestable wildlife (moose, caribou sheep) over predators and balanced, science-based wildlife management. This has and continues now to benefit, at least in theory, human consumers - sport hunters, commercial hunting guides and subsistence users at the expense of predators. We probably can debate this issue ad nauseum.

The public has a right to debate an articulated BOG policy with respect to predator/prey management. What I want to see is an open and honest acknowledgement by the BOG of what their strategic policy position is. If the BOG's position is that they want to favor harvestable wildlife at any cost, then they have an obligation to publicly say so. I suspect that the BOG knows full well how controversial predator control is in Alaska. So be it. But please BOG, don't tip-toe around this issue. Let Alaska citizens know, directly and specifically, what your strategic policy position is on this issue.

Comment: And of course, no one is arguing for broad generalizations across an entire gender.  You even quote Damore as saying that.

He's arguing that maybe in a world free from bias, the applicant pool for Google engineers wouldn't be 50/50.  It might be 40% women.  In which case, that should be the long-term goal: not 50/50.

The goal should be to treat everyone as an individual and look at their accomplishments and credentials.  We should also have a goal of treating people similarly through school and childhood so that people's natural interests are encouraged - even if they break typical gender stereotypes.

The 69-77% doesn't sound impressive at an individual level.  And it isn't.  But it is suggestive that if we treat everyone exactly the same, we can easily have more men or more women attracted to certain activities, hobbies or careers.

Comment: Politicians have long promised "pie in the sky", "a chicken in every pot", "shovel-ready jobs", or whatever impossible trinket they think will seduce their constituents to vote them into office. In the case of Trump, it was "bring the coal jobs back" in order to get votes in what used to be coal country but now, sadly, has become "OxyContin country", a forlorn and hopeless region of few job prospects. Those jobs, as Trump should know (but probably doesn't, or doesn't care"), won't come back because, like the timber and mill jobs in Oregon, they have been eliminated forever by automation or what we euphemistically call "productivity growth". But at his signing ceremony authorizing the dismantling of the Clean Power Plan, Trump said to the washed-up (in both senses) miners standing behind him, ""C'mon fellas, you know what this says? You're going back to work." Mission accomplished.

This was a cruel joke at the expense of the miners, our nation, and the world.

Comment: The middle bunch will side wherever their advantage lies. We have such a thing as "politeness" and it is all it takes. Calling it, derogatorily "political correctness" is counter-productive (if understandable, there are shades of grey), we all need to accommodate differences without buying into them. Over time, unless stoked, the fires of mistrust will die out.

I tend to use the term "courting" as the level of politeness demanded of all of us, I guess a Christian would call it "turning the other cheek". Of course, the consequences must be taken into account. The Nats failed to use their advantage to build respect rather than resentment. I guess that unwittingly we are continuing on that path, except that now we can see where it is going to lead. We're not to blame for creating the conditions, but we are guilty of perpetuating them.

And I think we have a case here that the shades of grey are subtle, very subtle. Robert Heinlein would insist that we do not throw sand into the cogs.

Comment: No - he's trying to make a point that Chicken Little's like yourself run circles in the ground every time a climate statistic doesn't identically match an "average" over the past 3 or 4 decades.

No one here seems to be disputing climate change theory... just getting a little sick of the Chicken Little's, who, every time the temperature fluctuates by a degree or two, suddenly break out the bullhorns and start furiously waving the climate change panic flags.  

One summer doesn't DENOTE climate change.  Climate is sometimes a few degrees above normal, and then a few degrees below normal.  That's why it's called climate (because of its variability).

If you want to talk trends over decades, then that's one thing... but don't take weather from ONE summer, and start trumpeting climate change alarms... because all you end up doing is causing people like myself to tune out your message, especially when the mean temperatures eventually revert back to the other side of the norms next summer.

Comment: As a divorced mom with 50% custody, I've found the clarity of responsibilities is amazing.  

During the weeks the kids are with me, I know "I'm on".  I've got full responsibility for childcare and domestic chores.  When they're not with me, I'm free to work late, or go out, or do what I wish with my time.  

In contrast, when we were married, about 80% of childcare and household tasks fell to me, even though both husband and I had similar work responsibilities.  Upon separation, I suddenly had free time, whereas ex was suddenly busy.

If I had to do it over, I would probably try to get agreement on an explicit division of responsibilities.  It could be by date (e.g. each person is fully responsible for 7 days at a time), or by task (e.g. you cook, I clean).  The worst is to have unvoiced expectations, leading to frustration.

Comment: One of my friends in Shanghai grew up on a dirt floor house in western China, now he drives an Audi.  When I 1st met him, he was about 30 and was just learning to drive. Watching him wolf down German pork knuckle in Bonn while drinking delicious german BEER, life doesn't suck.  I was 'the' driver in those days, and loved it.  1st time we ripped out of Kassel Germany together I immediately got a speeding ticket (camera cop) getting onto the autobhan while Bruce Springsteen's Born in the USA was blaring. I find that really remarkable, in one generation such a dramatic shift in quality of life in a place like China, dirt floors to high rises and Audis.  Most modern day Americans have totally lost touch with that aspect of modernization.

Comment: JF,  There is no record of any whippings taking place.  Actually, there is virtually no record of Oregon expelling anyone.  But there is a record of law enforcement telling a blackman to leave and his white neighbors coming to his defense and the law in the end not being enforced.  I suspect the real reason blacks didn't come to Oregon prior to WWII in any significant numbers is because there was nothing for them to come to Oregon for.  I seriously doubt blacks were even aware of the law, hence not an effective deterrent for moving to Oregon and basically useless in making blacks leave if they came.

Mostly what is written about these laws are the existence of them and a lot of postulating about them.

Comment: I find the very premise of "Civil Comments" antithetical to a civil society.  The very idea that a moderator, or a committee of moderators, or even a majority of posters can restrict me from posting simply because I don't vote others' posts "uncivil" when they think I should runs counter to the purpose of the 1st Amendment Freedom of Speech right, which was put there to protect speech we don't want to hear.  Speech we do find "civil" doesn't need protecting.   Some introspection is in order.

Comment: How is sarin gas different from barrel bombs? Drone strikes? Why act without authorization from Congress? If the barrel bombs and drone strike civilian deaths are shown on TV in the same graphic way that the gas casualties were, are countries justified to attack others militarily whenever dictators kill their own citizens? Where do we draw the line to halt a slippery slope of escalating violence and we becoming the world's policeman? A balance of powers in democratic governments helps prevent impulsive reactions based on TV images. We're also back to the stone-age dictum that might is right. I expected a more thoughtful column from Kristoff.
